intro: Serapias pseudocordigera var. brachyantha, commonly known as the narrow-leaved serapias, is a flowering plant native to the Iberian Peninsula. It belongs to the family Rockrose (Cistaceae) and is characterized by its compact, mat-forming growth habit. The plant produces showy, yellow-orange flowers with a distinctive hooded structure, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are narrow and linear, often covered in fine hairs, and it thrives in rocky, well-drained soils. This variety is noted for its resilience to drought and is often found in open, sunny habitats.
